title: CO2 emissions : Canada 1995 to 2018
summary: This line chart has an x axis representing Year and a y axis representing Emissions in million metric tons, with a total of 24 data points. The chart has 6 significant trends.
The longest trend is moderately positive which exists from 2014 to 2009.
Correspondingly, the next significant trend is extremely positive which exists from 2000 to 1995.
Additionally, the next significant trend is moderately negative which exists from 2018 to 2014.
On the other hand, the next significant trend is slightly positive which exists from 2009 to 2006.
Also, the next significant trend is slightly negative which exists from 2006 to 2003.
On the contrary, the next significant trend is moderately negative which exists from 2003 to 2000.
gold: Canada 's carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel and cement production reached about 568 million metric tons in 2018 , compared to 494 million metric tons in 1995 . A large percentage of global greenhouse gas emissions ( GHG ) are derived from the production and consumption of energy . In Canada , energy-related emissions account for an even higher share of total emissions due to extreme temperatures , large land area , and dispersed populations .
